articles.title: Watch CBA's Dhar on Commodities Outlook
articles.description: Watch CBA's Dhar on Commodities Outlook  Bloomberg
articles.content: It has been such a beginning of the year for oil. We know that. But fifth month in a row of gains in the month of April. You know it just keeps moving and moving a movie. Is this as high as oil goes. And in fact with China's locked down driven or I should say intensified maybe slowdown does that further chip away at the demand for oil and mean that this is going to be about as high as it gets. Sure. So look I think it's a great question in terms of where we are in the market. Look we saw all the geopolitics and all the disruptions linked to the Russia Ukraine conflict come to the fore shortly after that war began in early March. But when we talk about what's happened more recently with China and the lockdowns you know we're talking maybe one one and a half percent of global oil demand effectively being cut out because of the China Covid lockdowns particularly in April. Now when we're talking about the supply disruptions it's key to look at what's happening with Russian oil supply. And in April itself that's down roughly about 1 percent off of off the market too. So in some ways we have seen some relative balances in terms of supply and demand shocks. But when we talk about what's going to happen through the year. Keep in mind that we are going to see the physical market likely tighten from here as more and more Russian supply gets curtailed. The real caveat to all this is can we see India and China come in and buy more Russian crude. Because what we do know is Europe is certainly going to move away from crude throughout 2022. So this physical market story isn't over yet. Yes. We've come to a point where supply and demand disruptions have really balanced out for now. But when we talk about what's going to happen through the year watch the physical market and watch Russian supply. And there is a good risk here that markets tighten it. In a recent note you said you thought that on Brent crude I believe you're referring to Brent crude that the top would be about 110 dollars a barrel in the second quarter and even a bit weaker in the fourth quarter. Have you changed your mind at all as the war drags on as these questions about supplies from Russia who buys them and sells them oil supplies. That is how that goes. I guess part of my answer he thought we were near the top because of Brent crude tops out at 110 and Robert 109. There you we're pretty near the top. Yeah sure. Of course. Look at this. In terms of the picture that's that's evolved I think the key change to our outlook was just how quickly we were going to see the EU come in and really look to reduce their imports from Russia because that's the key caveat here in terms of how markets will look in the next few months because if we see Europe look aggressively away from Russian oil and they have to find that oil elsewhere we could see Brent or any benchmark outside of Russia tighten considerably. And that is something that wasn't in the forecast of 110 in Q2 and Q3. But that is that is really the risk in the market right now in terms of markets prices coming off by the end of this year. I'd say it's really looking at at a US oil story that can we see US oil supply come up. Can we see enough demand destruction for markets to rebalance by the end of the year. That's really what we're talking about prices falling by year end. But when we talk about the next few months I'm keeping a very close eye on this German report that they're looking that that by the end of summer they may be okay without Russian oil imports. That's a very aggressive move for the next few months. And that's certainly tighten markets. The other weakening demand piece of course is China and Vivek just taking a look at this chart which shows that deepening contraction that we see are both in manufacturing as well as non manufacturing the pair my numbers that really came in pretty dire over the weekend. The manufacturing and non non manufacturing gauges both falling to two year lows and the fact that the Covid-19 Covid zero strategy. But also these lockdowns were not really part of the peace either. When it comes to expectations for China how does that play into the demand side of the story. Sure it's certainly more critical than we talk about base metal and bulk commodities particularly iron ore. And what we're seeing so far is that these lockdowns has certainly hurt near-term demand sentiment. But I think the redeeming picture and one that the markets are looking forward to is how is China going to achieve its economic growth target. We are more infrastructure spending and trying to provide relief to the property sector. And both of which have been mentioned by the Politburo in their quarterly meetings from Friday onward. So you know we certainly have some color that that we are going to see some demand rebound. The question is that can only really happen once these lockdowns end. And and you know for us that's a second half story. But certainly that's going to be a key story in terms of that price increase in the second half of this year. Yeah it's interesting because for copper aluminium we saw that initial reaction to the pledge to boost our economic stimulus and activity. Right. But that the hope that the gains really didn't hold. So what the market's really looking for when it comes to a bit more conviction. So you want to see action. Right now we've seen a big allowance in terms of infrastructure. But you can only get that activity on the ground happening once we see these disruptions to to mobility to two that are linked to these Covid-19 lockdowns. And you kind of saw that in the PMI if you sort of see the construction subcomponents of the known manufacturing PMI that dropped quite sharply last month and that tells you that it is difficult to get those infrastructure projects delivered. If we have these these restrictions on movement and we we need to see those end. And our view is that look Shanghai is probably going to see the worst of it. And coming into like the restrictions in Beijing and what we've seen coming forward could we see these these Covid-19 restrictions eased from from here on in. And really that's the expectation that look. Could this be. Was April going to be the worst than I think is going to get better from here. Because if that's the outlook then certainly second half is going to be a positive period for four Chinese commodities consumption. Just hard to say what the Chinese leadership is going to decide whether they soften this up a bit or not. But I won't ask you about the dollar. It has been climbing steadily. It kind of stalled out a bit on Friday ahead of the Federal Reserve meeting on Wednesday where they're supposed to start this aggressive rate hike path. How how if any way do you factor the dollar's path into your outlook for commodities. Sure so when it comes to more the financially linked commodity so you're looking at base metals or oil. The rising U.S. dollar is a negative force. But what we've seen play out is that there are other factors and whether that is the Russia supply issue or what's going to happen in China that has provided a more dominant force on on commodity prices then see what's happening with the US dollar. But certainly that factors in. But whether it's primary secondary tertiary right now it's looking more to be in the background. When we talk about some of these these key commodities right now. So if you were going to invest. If I were going to invest I said Vivek where do I want to make money on commodities right now. How do I do it. You know Warren Buffett just took a pretty decent Chevron straight stake and just about quadrupled it. You know Chevron announced it's going to do more stock buybacks et cetera. But what would you see. What's at play here for people who think this is going to last and they want to invest in it. Sure. So look it really depend on horizons if you're looking at it at what is going to happen in the next 10 years and this transition that we're talking about we're really going to see investment in base metals and copper for instance if you have to see what what the status quo is and what is expected until 2030. We're talking maybe 25 percent increase in copper supply. But if we have to hit say one and a half degree targets by 2030 we need to see copper supply growth maybe say 40 percent. So how well positioned is the market to supply that extra copper given that these ambitions are increasing. And that's where the opportunity is more in the longer term. And so you know copper and nickel are certainly the larger markets where where that investment can happen. But lithium has certainly shown its cards in terms of just how much is needed. And the price increases we've seen there certainly indicate that. But when you look at at fossil fuels if your outlook is over the next few years next four four years even you know natural gas for instance those markets know certainly look under invested in. If you think about how Europe is going to cut itself away from from Russia gas market you know look to be very tight for the foreseeable future. And LNG supply prices are likely going to be elevated. You know likely for years relative to what they were a year ago. So you know I think fossil fuels offer an opportunity in the near term. But if you're talking longer term then suddenly base metals and battery metals.
articles.summary: Now when we're talking about the supply disruptions it's key to look at what's happening with Russian oil supply. Have you changed your mind at all as the war drags on as these questions about supplies from Russia who buys them and sells them oil supplies. In terms of the picture that's that's evolved I think the key change to our outlook was just how quickly we were going to see the EU come in and really look to reduce their imports from Russia because that's the key caveat here in terms of how markets will look in the next few months because if we see Europe look aggressively away from Russian oil and they have to find that oil elsewhere we could see Brent or any benchmark outside of Russia tighten considerably. I'd say it's really looking at at a US oil story that can we see US oil supply come up.

articles.authorsByline: Maanvi Singh, Jennifer Rankin, Helen Livingstone, Harry Taylor
articles.title: Russia-Ukraine war: what we know on day 68 of the invasion
articles.description: Russia-Ukraine war: what we know on day 68 of the invasion  The Guardian
articles.content:
• None The first evacuees from the besieged Azovstal steel plant in Mariupol are due to arrive in the Ukrainian-controlled city of Zaporizhzhia on Monday morning, Ukrainian president Volodymyr Zelenskiy said. On Sunday around 100 civilians were evacuated from plant, the last redoubt for Ukrainian forces in the city. Zelenskiy said he hoped that “all the necessary conditions” would be met to allow the evacuation to continue on Monday.
• None US House speaker, Nancy Pelosi, has become the highest-ranking US official to visit Ukraine since the outbreak of war, where she met president Zelenskiy. In a press conference afterwards, Pelosi said that the US would not be bullied. “If they are making threats, you cannot back down,” she said. Pelosi was presented with the order of Princess of Olga medal by Zelenskiy.
• None Russian foreign minister Sergei Lavrov has denied that Russia is demanding the “surrender” of Zelenskiy as a condition for peace, or that Russia would attempt to claim victory in Ukraine by 9 May. “The pace of the operation in Ukraine depends, first of all, on the need to minimise any risks for the civilian population and Russian military personnel,” he told Italian broadcaster Mediaset.
• None Russia’s latest strikes, including on grain warehouses and residential neighbourhoods, “prove once again that the war against Ukraine is a war of extermination for the Russian army,” Zelenskiy has said in his nightly address on Sunday, asking, “What could be Russia’s strategic success in this war?” The “ruined lives of people and the burned or stolen property will give nothing to Russia.”
• None German chancellor Olaf Scholz has pledged to continue supporting Ukraine with money, aid and weapons, saying a pacifist approach to the war is “outdated.” His remarks to a May Day rally in Dusseldorf were an implicit rebuke to a group of intellectuals, lawyers and creatives who condemned Russia’s war of aggression in an open letter, but urged Scholz not to send heavy weapons to Ukraine. Opposition leader Friedrich Merz is reportedly set to travel to Kyiv on Monday.
• None Pope Francis described the war in Ukraine as a “macabre regression of humanity” that makes him “suffer and cry”, in a Sunday noon address in St Peter’s Square. “My thoughts go immediately to the Ukrainian city of Mariupol, the city of Mary, barbarously bombarded and destroyed,” he said of the mostly Russian-controlled south-eastern port city, which is named after the Virgin Mary.
• None The governor of the north eastern city of Kharkiv urged people not to leave shelters on Sunday due to intense shelling. Posting on Telegram, Oleh Synyehubov said: “In connection with the intense shelling, we urge residents of the northern and eastern districts of Kharkiv, in particular Saltivka, not to leave the shelter during the day without urgency.”
• None Russia’s defence ministry has confirmed an attack on an airfield near Odesa on Saturday. It said its forces had destroyed a runway and hangar at an airfield, which contained weapons supplied by the US and EU.
• None A fire broke out on Sunday at a Russian defence ministry site in Belgorod, close to the border with Ukraine, the region’s governor said, injuring one person. “On the the borders of three municipalities - Borisov, Belgorod and the urban district of Yakovlevsky - a fire broke out at one of the defence ministry’s facilities,” the governor of Russia’s Belgorod region, Vyacheslav Gladkov, said on Telegram.
• None The European Union could phase out Russian oil imports by the end of the year, under the latest set of sanctions against Vladimir Putin’s war machine being discussed in Brussels. The European Commission president, Ursula von der Leyen, has said for weeks that the EU is working on sanctions targeting Russian oil, but the key question is how and when the commodity is phased out.

articles.title: EU energy ministers hold crisis talks after Russian gas cuts
articles.description: EU energy ministers hold crisis talks after Russian gas cuts  Reuters
articles.content:
The Astora natural gas depot, which is the largest natural gas storage in Western Europe, is pictured in Rehden, Germany, March 16, 2022. Astora is part of the Gazprom Germania Group. REUTERS/Fabian Bimmer

BRUSSELS, May 2 (Reuters) - Energy ministers from European Union countries hold emergency talks on Monday, as the bloc strives for a united response to Moscow's demand that European buyers pay for Russian gas in roubles or face their supply being cut off.

Russia halted gas supplies to Bulgaria and Poland last week after they refused to meet its demand to effectively pay in roubles.

Those countries already planned to stop using Russian gas this year and say they can cope with the stoppage, but it has raised fears that other EU countries, including Europe's gas-reliant economic powerhouse Germany, could be next.

It has also threatened to crack the EU's united front against Russia amid disagreement on the right course of action.

With many European companies facing gas payment deadlines later this month, EU states have a pressing need to clarify whether companies can keep buying the fuel without breaching the EU's sanctions against Russia over its invasion of Ukraine.

Moscow has said foreign gas buyers must deposit euros or dollars into an account at the privately owned Russian bank Gazprombank, which would convert them into roubles.

The European Commission has told countries that complying with Russia's scheme could breach EU sanctions, while also suggesting countries could make sanctions-compliant payments if they declare the payment complete once it has been made in euros and before its conversion into roubles.

After Bulgaria, Denmark, Greece, Poland, Slovakia and others last week urged clearer advice, Brussels is drafting extra guidance.

Russia on Friday said it saw no problem with its decree, which considers the buyer's obligation fulfilled only after the hard currency has been converted to roubles.

While Bulgaria and Poland refused to engage with Moscow's scheme, Germany has echoed the Commission's workaround to allow companies to pay, and Hungary has said buyers can engage with Russia's mechanism. read more

Payments in roubles can help to shelter Russia's economy from the impact of sanctions, while the fuel revenues can help to finance what it calls a special military operation.

EU countries have paid more than 45 billion euros ($47.43 billion) to Russia for gas and oil since it invaded Ukraine on Feb. 24, research organisation the Centre for Research on Energy and Clean Air found.

Russia supplies 40% of EU gas and 26% of its oil imports, a dependency that means Germany and others have so far resisted calls for an abrupt halt to Russian fuel imports for fear of economic damage.

The EU is edging towards a ban on imports of Russian oil by the end of the year, diplomats said, after talks between the Commission and EU countries at the weekend ahead of meetings this week.

Ambassadors will discuss at a meeting on Wednesday a sixth package of EU sanctions against Moscow being drafted by the Commission.

Ministers on Monday will also discuss the need to urgently secure non-Russian gas supplies and fill storage, as countries brace for supply shocks.

Dependency on Russian gas varies between countries, but analysts have said an immediate total cut-off of Russian gas would plunge countries, including Germany, into recession and require emergency measures such as factory closures to cope.

Austria, Hungary, Italy and Slovakia also had reservations over the weekend about the idea of an oil embargo, diplomats said.

The Commission will later this month unveil plans to end Europe's dependency on Russian fossil fuels by 2027, including by expanding renewable energy and renovating buildings to consume less.
articles.summary:
Energy ministers from European Union countries hold emergency talks on Monday, as the bloc strives for a united response to Moscow's demand that European buyers pay for Russian gas in roubles or face their supply being cut off. 

Those countries already planned to stop using Russian gas this year and say they can cope with the stoppage, but it has raised fears that other EU countries, including Europe's gas-reliant economic powerhouse Germany, could be next. 

Russia supplies 40% of EU gas and 26% of its oil imports, a dependency that means Germany and others have so far resisted calls for an abrupt halt to Russian fuel imports for fear of economic damage. 

Dependency on Russian gas varies between countries, but analysts have said an immediate total cut-off of Russian gas would plunge countries, including Germany, into recession and require emergency measures such as factory closures to cope.
